quest_title: The area enclosed between the parabolas \(y^{2} =4a(x+a)\) and \(y^{2} =4b(b-x)\) is :
explanation_txt:
Given parabolas are:

\(y^2 = 4a(x+a) \)

\[\Rightarrow x = \cfrac{y^2}{4a}-a \]

And

\[ y^2 = 4b(b-x)\]

\[ \Rightarrow x =b- \cfrac{y^2}{4b} \]

The points of intersection are:

\[ \cfrac{y^2}{4a} - a = b - \cfrac{y^2}{4b} \]

\[ \Rightarrow \cfrac{y^2}{4} \left(\cfrac{a+b}{ab} \right) = a+b \]

\[ \Rightarrow y^2 = 4ab \]

\[ \Rightarrow y = \pm 2 \sqrt{ab} \]

So, the area is:

\[ \begin{align} A & = \left| \int_{-2\sqrt{ab}}^{2\sqrt{ab}} (a+b)\left(1 - \cfrac{y^2}{4ab} \right) dy \right| \\ & = (a+b) \left|y - \cfrac{y^3}{12ab} \right|_{-2\sqrt{ab}}^{2\sqrt{ab}} \\ & = 2(a+b) \left| 2 \sqrt{ab} - \cfrac{8 \sqrt{ab}}{12} \right| \\ & = 2(a+b) \sqrt{ab} \cfrac{4}{3} \\ &= \cfrac{8}{3} (a+b)\sqrt {ab} \end{align} \]

[Try solving with \(a=1,b=1\)]
question_plain_title: The area enclosed between the parabolas and is :
explanation_plain_text:
Given parabolas are:

And

The points of intersection are:

So, the area is:

[Try solving with ]

explanation_txt:
\(\text { Area }(\mathrm{A})=|\overrightarrow{\mathrm{A}}||\overrightarrow{\mathrm{B}}| \sin \theta\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { Or, } \cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{AB}=\mathrm{AB} \sin \theta} \\ {\text { Or, } \sin \theta=\cfrac{1}{2}=\sin 30^{\circ}}\end{array}\)

\(\therefore \theta=30^{\circ}\)

quest_title: A body falls freely from the top of a tower and it falls \(\left( \cfrac{7}{16} \right) {}^{th}\) of total distance in last second. The time taken by body to complete the motion is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}} \\ {\cfrac{7 \mathrm{h}}{16}=\cfrac{\mathrm{g}}{2}(2 \mathrm{t}-1)} \\ {\text { or, } \cfrac{7}{16} \times \cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}=\cfrac{\mathrm{g}}{2}(2 \mathrm{t}-1)} \\ {\text { or, } 7 \mathrm{t}^{2}=32 \mathrm{t}-16} \\ {\text { or, } 7 \mathrm{t}^{2}-32 \mathrm{t}+16=0}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { or, } \mathrm{t}=\cfrac{+32 \pm \sqrt{32^{2}-4 \times 7 \times 16}}{2 \times 7}} \\ {\qquad \begin{aligned} &=\cfrac{32 \pm 24}{14} \\ \text { Taking }+& \text { ve sign } \\ \mathrm{t} &=\cfrac{56}{14}=4 \end{aligned}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A body falls freely from the top of a tower and it falls of total distance in last second. The time taken by body to complete the motion is

quest_title: A pump motor is used to deliver at a certain rate from a given pipe. To increase the rate two times from same pipe, the power of motor must be increased to
explanation_txt:
\(P=F \cdot v=\cfrac{V}{t} \cdot \rho v^{2}=\rho A v^{3}\)
If rate is made two times, then \(v^{\prime}=2 v\) so

\(P^{\prime}=\rho A v'^{3}=\rho A(2 v)^{3}=8 \rho A v^{3}\)
\(\therefore\) Power must be increased 8 times.
question_plain_title: A pump motor is used to deliver at a certain rate from a given pipe. To increase the rate two times from same pipe, the power of motor must be increased to
explanation_plain_text:
If rate is made two times, then so


Power must be increased 8 times.

quest_title: Retarding potential of 3.38v is required to stop the emission of electron from metallic surface by radiation of 2000\(\mathring{A}\). The threshold wavelength is
explanation_txt:
\(\phi=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda}-\mathrm{KE}\)
or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda_{0}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda}-\mathrm{ev_s}\)
or, \(\lambda_{0}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\left(\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda}-\mathrm{ev_s}\right)}\)
\(=\cfrac{6.62 \times 10^{-34} \times 3 \times 10^{8}}{\left(\cfrac{6.62 \times 10^{-34} \times 3 \times 10^{8}}{2000 \times 10^{-10}}-1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 3.38\right)}\)
\(=4.4 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{m}\)

quest_title: Eight small drops, each of radius \(\text{r}\) and having same charge \(\text{q}\) are combined to form a big drop. The ratio of potential of big drop to small drop is
explanation_txt:
Volume of 1 big \(\mathrm{drop}=\) vol. of 8 small drops

Or, \(\quad V=8 \mathrm{V}\)

\(\cfrac{4}{3} \pi R^{3}=8 \times \cfrac{4}{3} \pi r^{3} \Rightarrow R=2 r\)

Potentials of big drop & small drop are:

\(\begin{array}{l}{V=\cfrac{Q}{C} \ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (1) }} \\ {v=\cfrac{q}{c} \ldots \ldots \ldots \text { (2) }}\end{array}\)

Dividing \((1)\) by \((2)\)

\(\cfrac{V}{v}=\cfrac{Q}{C} \times \cfrac{C}{q}\)

\(\cfrac{V}{v}=\cfrac{8 q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} R} \times \cfrac{4 \pi \varepsilon_0 \mathrm{r}}{q}\)

\(\cfrac{V}{v}=\cfrac{8 r}{2 r}\)

\(\therefore \quad V : v=4 : 1\)

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: A cell is connected between the points A and C of a circular conductor ABCD of centre O, \(\angle\)AOC = \(60^\circ\) of B\({}_{1}\) and B\({}_{2}\) are magnitudes of the magnetic fields at O due to current in ABC and ADC respectively, then the ratio of B\({}_{1}\)/B\({}_{2}\) is
explanation_txt:
Let the lengths of ABC and ADC parts be \(l_{1} \) and \(l_{2}\) respectively then

\(\cfrac{l_{1}}{l_{2}}=\cfrac{360-60}{60}=5\)

\(\text { Again, } \cfrac{i_{1}}{l_{2}}=\cfrac{l_{2}}{l_{1}}=\cfrac{1}{5} \Rightarrow i_{2}=5 i_{1} \)

\(B_{1}=\cfrac{5}{6}\left(\cfrac{\mu_{0} i_{1}}{2 r}\right) \text { and } B_{2}=\cfrac{1}{6}\left(\cfrac{\mu_{0} i_{2}}{2 }\right)=\cfrac{5}{6} \cfrac{\mu_{0} i_{1}}{2 r} \)

\(\cfrac{B_{1}}{B_{2}}=1 \)

quest_title: The driver of a car travelling with a speed 30m/sec towards a hill sounds a horn of frequency of 600Hz. If the velocity of sound in air is 330m/sec, the frequency of reflected sound heard by the driver is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{f}^{\prime} &=\left(\cfrac{v+v_{0}}{v-v_{s}}\right) \times \mathrm{f}=\left(\cfrac{330+30}{330-30}\right) \times 600 \\ &=720 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: In hydrogen spectrum \(\lambda\)\({}_{3}\)&\(\lambda\)\({}_{2}\) are the wavelengths of radiation emitted due to transition from second and first excited state to ground state. The ratio of \(\cfrac{\lambda_3}{\lambda_2}\) is
explanation_txt:
For \(2^{\text {nd }}\) excited state
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda_{3}}=\mathrm{E}_{3}-\mathrm{E}_{1}\)
or, \(\lambda_{3}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\left(-\cfrac{13.6}{9}+13.6\right)}\)
\(\lambda_{3}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{13.6 \times \cfrac{8}{9}} \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots (1)\)
For \(1^{\text {st}}\) excited state
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\lambda_{2}}=\mathrm{E}_{2}-\mathrm{E}_{1}\)
or, \(\lambda_{2}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{\left(\cfrac{-13.6}{4}+13.6\right)}=\cfrac{\mathrm{hc}}{13.6 \times \cfrac{3}{4}} \ldots \ldots . .(2)\)
Dividing ( 1) by ( 2)
\(\cfrac{\lambda_{3}}{\lambda_{2}}=\cfrac{9}{8} \times \cfrac{3}{4}=\cfrac{27}{32}\)

quest_title: The equation of the hyperbola whose directrix is \(x + 2 y = 1\), focus (2, 1) and eccentricity 2 will be:
explanation_txt:
Let,

\( D:x + 2 y = 1 \\ S( 2,1 ) \\ e = 2 \) be directrix, focus and eccentricity respectively.

If \( P(x,y) \) be any point on the hyperbola, by definition,

\( PS = e PD \\ (x-2)^2 + (y-1)^2 = 4 \cfrac{(x+2y-1)^2}{5} \)

Simplifying we get,

\( x ^ { 2 } - 11 y ^ { 2 } - 16 x y - 12 x + 6 y + 21 = 0 \)

quest_title: In Balmer series of hydrogen atom spectrum which electronic transition causes third line
explanation_txt:
In Balmer series

First line is due to transition : third to second

Second line is due to transition : fourth to second

Third line is due to transition : figth to second

quest_title: The vector sum of two forces is perpendicular to their vector differences. In that case, the forces
ans1_txt: Are equal to each other in magnitude
ans2_txt: Are not equal to each other in magnitude
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { If two vectors are perpendicular, then their dot product } } \\ { \text { must be equal to zero. According to problem } } \\ { ( \vec { A } + \vec { B } ) \cdot ( \vec { A } - \vec { B } ) = 0 \Rightarrow \vec { A } \cdot \vec { A } - \vec { A } \cdot \vec { B } + \vec { B } \cdot \vec { A } - \vec { B } \cdot \vec { B } = 0 } \\ { \Rightarrow A ^ { 2 } - B ^ { 2 } = 0 \Rightarrow A ^ { 2 } = B ^ { 2 } } \\ { \therefore A = B \text { i.e. two vectors are equal to each other in } } \\ { \text { magnitude. } } \end{array}\)
question_plain_title: The vector sum of two forces is perpendicular to their vector differences. In that case, the forces
ans1_plain_text: Are equal to each other in magnitude
ans2_plain_text: Are not equal to each other in magnitude

quest_title: A person can see clearly object upto 3m. The power of lens needed to see the object at 12m will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{v}=-3 \mathrm{m}\) and \(\mathrm{u}=12 \mathrm{m}\)

\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{\mathrm{uv}}{\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{v}}=\cfrac{12(-3)}{12-3}=\cfrac{-36}{9}=-4 \mathrm{m}\)

\(\mathrm{P}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{1}{-4}=-0.25 \mathrm{D}\)

quest_title: The intensity of x-ray decreases by 20% on passing through a glass slab of certain thickness. If x-ray of same intensity passes through two glass slab of same thickness then intensity decreases by
explanation_txt:
For one slab:

\(\mathrm{I}^{\prime}=80 \%\) of \(\mathrm{I}=0.8 \mathrm{I}\)

For second slab:

\(\mathrm{I}^{\prime \prime}=64 \%\) of \(\mathrm{I}^{\prime}=0.64 \mathrm{I}\)

or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{I}^{\prime \prime}}{\mathrm{I}}=0.64\)
\(\begin{aligned} \% \text { reduce } &=\left(1-\cfrac{\mathrm{I}^{\prime \prime}}{\mathrm{I}}\right) \times 100 \% \\ &=(1-0.64) \times 100 \%=36 \% \end{aligned}\)

or, \(\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{6}=\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{2}}\)
or, \(t=12\) hrs.

quest_title: Zone refining is a method to obtain
explanation_txt:
Zone refining is one of the methods of the refining of the ores to obtain highly pure metals.

It is based on the principle that the impurities are more soluble in the molten form the metal than they are in the solid state of the metal.
question_plain_title: Zone refining is a method to obtain
explanation_plain_text:
Zone refining is one of the methods of the refining of the ores to obtain highly pure metals.

It is based on the principle that the impurities are more soluble in the molten form the metal than they are in the solid state of the metal.

quest_title: A Plano convex lens when silvered on the plane side behaves like a concave mirror of focal length 30cm. When the convex side is silvered then it behaves like concave mirror of focal length 10cm. The refractive index of material is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{ll}{\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{2}{\mathrm{f}_{l}}} & {\therefore \mathrm{f}_{l}=60 \mathrm{cm}} \\ {\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}^{\prime}}=\cfrac{2}{\mathrm{f}_{l}}+\cfrac{2}{\mathrm{R}}} & {\therefore \mathrm{R}=30 \mathrm{cm}} \\ {\cfrac{1}{10}=\cfrac{1}{30}+\cfrac{2}{\mathrm{R}}} & {} \\ {\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{1}}=(\mu-1) \cfrac{1}{\mathrm{R}}} & {} \\ {\text { or, }(\mu-1)=\cfrac{30}{60}} & {\text { or, } \mu=1.5}\end{array}\)
